content: Write a tragic monologue for an astronaut stranded on Mars, with no hope of rescue. The astronaut should reflect on his life and express regret over never having seen the Northern Lights.

(Muttering to himself, staring at the endless expanse of red dust)

"Of all the places to be marooned, it had to be Mars. I always thought I'd see the cosmos from up here, among the stars, not stuck on some barren rock, millions of miles from home. They say Mars is the god of war, but to me, it's just a silent grave.

I remember when I first signed up for this mission, all those years ago. The thrill, the adventure, the promise of pushing humanity's boundaries. I was young, full of dreams and optimism. Now, looking back, it seems so naive. So foolish.

There are moments when the solitude gets to me, when the silence is deafening. I miss Earth more than I can say. The smell of rain, the taste of fresh fruit, the sound of laughter. But most of all, I regret never getting to see the Northern Lights. Oh, how I've heard about their ethereal beauty, those dancing ribbons of color across the night sky. I've seen pictures, of course, but it's not the same as experiencing it firsthand.

I used to tell myself that being an astronaut was worth missing out on such wonders. That exploring space was a higher calling, that my sacrifices were for the greater good. But now, alone on this desert planet, I can't help but question that. What good is all this knowledge, all this discovery, if I can't even enjoy the simplest pleasures back home?

I think about my family, my friends, and wonder if they ever think about me. Do they remember the man who dared to reach for the stars, only to be left stranded among them? Or have they moved on, their memories of me fading like footprints in the sand?

In my cabin, surrounded by equipment and supplies, I sometimes pretend that I'm not really here, that this is all just a bad dream. That any minute now, I'll wake up back on Earth, ready to embark on another mission, another adventure. But reality always sets in, harsh and unforgiving.

I've tried to make the best of my situation, to keep myself busy with experiments and maintenance tasks. But in the end, it's just a way to distract myself from the inevitable. I know that rescue is impossible. The distance is too great, the resources required too vast. I'm alone, and I always will be.

As I sit here, watching the sun set behind the horizon, painting the sky with shades of orange and pink, I can't help but feel a sense of irony. Here I am, on a planet named after the god of war, facing my own personal battle – the battle to accept my fate.

Maybe, in some twisted way, this is my destiny. To be the first human to live and die on Mars, a testament to humanity's ambition and folly. Perhaps, centuries from now, when Mars is colonized, people will look back on my story and remember me as a pioneer, a martyr for the cause of space exploration.

But for now, I'm just a lonely soul, trapped on a distant world, wishing I could have seen the Northern Lights one last time.

(Fading into silence, lost in thought)

**End of Monologue**
